image.altText: A densely crowded street

items.synopsis: A glimpse into the possible Australia of 2063 has been laid out in a major government report, which offers warnings as the country gets older, warmer and faces a more fragmented global order.

title.children: Major report lays out vision of older and warmer Australia in 2063

image.altText: Three women speaking with news microphones in front of them.

items.synopsis: Former school principal Malka Leifer is sentenced in a Melbourne court for 18 sexual offences, including rape and indecent assault. Follow live.

title.children: Abuse survivor hails 'momentous day' as former principal sentenced

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: There was a massive media pack waiting to hear from sisters Dassi Erlich, Elly Sapper and Nicole Meyer after Leifer's 15-year sentence was handed down. All three sisters came forward with abuse allegations against Leifer more than a decade ago. A jury found Leifer guilty of assaulting Ms Erlich and Ms Sapper, and not guilty of offences against Ms Meyer. Ms Erlich says as the judge outlined the profound vulnerability of her and her sister during the abuse, she felt again the "pain of my younger self". "I could feel those emotions coming up as the judge was speaking, and then knowing that's not where we are anymore, that we were not powerless anymore," she says.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Sisters united in relief after years of anguish

children.content: There was a massive media pack waiting to hear from sisters Dassi Erlich, Elly Sapper and Nicole Meyer after Leifer's 15-year sentence was handed down.

props.alt: Nicole Meyer, Elly Sapper and Dassi Erlich outside court.

children.content: Nicole Meyer, Elly Sapper and Dassi Erlich outside court.
(ABC News: Danielle Bonica)
All three sisters came forward with abuse allegations against Leifer more than a decade ago.
A jury found Leifer guilty of assaulting Ms Erlich and Ms Sapper, and not guilty of offences against Ms Meyer.

props.alt: Nicole Meyer, Elly Sapper and Dassi Erlich outside court with massive media pack.

children.content: The sisters addressed a large group of journalists after the sentence.
(ABC News: Danielle Bonica)
Ms Erlich says as the judge outlined the profound vulnerability of her and her sister during the abuse, she felt again the "pain of my younger self".
"I could feel those emotions coming up as the judge was speaking, and then knowing that's not where we are anymore, that we were not powerless anymore," she says.

props.alt: Dassi Erlich, Nicole Meyer and Elly Sapper outside court.

children.content: Dassi Erlich, Nicole Meyer and Elly Sapper outside court.
(ABC News: Danielle Bonica)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Flanked by her sisters outside court, Dassi Erlich says it's been a "traumatising" and "destabilising" path to justice. "We are here today because we did not give up," she says. "And while we know that the onus of fighting for justice should not be up to survivors, this fight was never just for us. "We are showing that the voices of survivors will not and cannot be silenced, no matter the obstacles." "Today really marks the end of this chapter of our lives and opens the chapter to us healing. "To any other survivors in this nightmare: you are never alone, we are all behind you."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Dassi Erlich tells other abuse survivors 'you are never alone'

children.content: Flanked by her sisters outside court, Dassi Erlich says it's been a "traumatising" and "destabilising" path to justice.
"We are here today because we did not give up," she says.
"And while we know that the onus of fighting for justice should not be up to survivors, this fight was never just for us.
"We are showing that the voices of survivors will not and cannot be silenced, no matter the obstacles."
"Today really marks the end of this chapter of our lives and opens the chapter to us healing.
"To any other survivors in this nightmare: you are never alone, we are all behind you."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Outside court, Elly Sapper says the jailing of her abuser was a "momentous day". "We feel overwhelmed and grateful that the legal system has recognised and validated the extreme impact of abuse by female perpetrators," she says. "Malka Leifer has finally been held accountable. "Today's ruling of 15 years recognises the harm and pain that Malka Leifer caused each one of us to suffer over so many years. "Trauma from sexual abuse is a lifelong sentence. "While no amount of years will ever be sufficient, we are so relieved that Malka Leifer is now in prison ... and cannot prey on anyone else."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Elly Sapper hails 'momentous day'

children.content: Outside court, Elly Sapper says the jailing of her abuser was a "momentous day".
"We feel overwhelmed and grateful that the legal system has recognised and validated the extreme impact of abuse by female perpetrators," she says.
"Malka Leifer has finally been held accountable.
"Today's ruling of 15 years recognises the harm and pain that Malka Leifer caused each one of us to suffer over so many years.
"Trauma from sexual abuse is a lifelong sentence.
"While no amount of years will ever be sufficient, we are so relieved that Malka Leifer is now in prison ... and cannot prey on anyone else."

image.altText: Smoke arises from the site of a jet crash near Moscow.

items.synopsis: Warlord Yevgeny Prigozhin was on the passenger list for a private jet that crashed between Moscow and St Petersburg, Russian state media is reporting.

title.children: Prigozhin 'died as a result of the actions of traitors to Russia' says Wagner group, confirming plane crash

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Morning has broken in Russia, it's around 7:30am in Moscow. We're seeing some fresh photos from the site of the plane crash in the Tver region, just to the north of the capital.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: New photos from the crash site have emerged

children.content: Morning has broken in Russia, it's around 7:30am in Moscow. We're seeing some fresh photos from the site of the plane crash in the Tver region, just to the north of the capital.

props.alt: A man wearing a black raincoat stands next to a tripod and camera, looking at part of a plane wing

children.content: A cameraman films wreckage of the private jet
(Reuters: Marina Lystseva)

children.content: The wreckage of the private jet linked to Prigozhin, near the crash site.
(Reuters: Marina Lystseva)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: What's been the Ukrainian reaction to the assassination? - Evan. Hi Evan, it's been fairly limited so far. We haven't seen any public comments from Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy yet. Mykhailo Podolyak, an adviser to the president, said earlier that it was "worth waiting for the fog of war to clear". Ukraine's Ministry of Defence, meanwhile, has been sharing videos on Twitter to mark the country's Independence Day. In an earlier post, the ministry said it wanted to initiate "a marathon of gratitude for the friends and partners who came to the aid of our country". Here's the herogram for Australia:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Still no official response from Ukraine

children.content: What's been the Ukrainian reaction to the assassination?
- Evan

Hi Evan, it's been fairly limited so far. We haven't seen any public comments from Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy yet. Mykhailo Podolyak, an adviser to the president, said earlier that it was "worth waiting for the fog of war to clear".

Ukraine's Ministry of Defence, meanwhile, has been sharing videos on Twitter to mark the country's Independence Day. In an earlier post, the ministry said it wanted to initiate "a marathon of gratitude for the friends and partners who came to the aid of our country". Here's the herogram for Australia:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: How do you think Wagner troops will react to new leadership being installed at Wagner Group? Will they rise against the Russian government? - Rick Daly. Thanks for the question, Rick. I've passed this onto our global affairs editor John Lyons. He says: "It's too early to tell how Wagner fighters will react to these developments. I think it depends whether a strong new leader emerges who is able to hold together the group. "Also, if the Wagner fighters believe that Vladimir Putin was behind the crash then some may want to take revenge. But I think others will think that it's much safer to go back to Wagner's traditional business model – providing military services in Africa and Syria." The Institute for the Study of War, which has been monitoring the war in Ukraine since it began, has also just published its daily update — Prigozhin's presumed death is the headline news. It writes: "Wagner PMC's future without a leader remains uncertain. A Russian news aggregator claimed that the Wagner council of commanders is currently meeting … to prepare a joint statement and announce what will happen to Wagner in the near future. "Prigozhin and Utkin were undeniably the faces of Wagner, and their assassinations will have dramatic impacts on Wagner's command structure and the Wagner brand. "Wagner commanders and fighters may begin to fear for their lives or become demoralised. The Russian Ministry of Defence and Kremlin's inroads into Wagner's operations and the absence of Prigozhin – who would fight for new opportunities for Wagner personnel – may further lead to the degradation of the Wagner grouping."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What will Wagner troops do next?

children.content: How do you think Wagner troops will react to new leadership being installed at Wagner Group? Will they rise against the Russian government?
- Rick Daly
Thanks for the question, Rick. I've passed this onto our
global affairs editor John Lyons
. He says:
"It's too early to tell how Wagner fighters will react to these developments. I think it depends whether a strong new leader emerges who is able to hold together the group.

"Also, if the Wagner fighters believe that Vladimir Putin was behind the crash then some may want to take revenge. But I think others will think that it's much safer to go back to Wagner's traditional business model – providing military services in Africa and Syria."
The
Institute for the Study of War
, which has been monitoring the war in Ukraine since it began, has also just published
its daily update — Prigozhin's presumed death is the headline news
. It writes:

"Wagner PMC's future without a leader remains uncertain. A Russian news aggregator claimed that the Wagner council of commanders is currently meeting … to prepare a joint statement and announce what will happen to Wagner in the near future.
"Prigozhin and Utkin were undeniably the faces of Wagner, and their assassinations will have dramatic impacts on Wagner's command structure and the Wagner brand.

"Wagner commanders and fighters may begin to fear for their lives or become demoralised. The Russian Ministry of Defence and Kremlin's inroads into Wagner's operations and the absence of Prigozhin – who would fight for new opportunities for Wagner personnel – may further lead to the degradation of the Wagner grouping."
